follow_up_questions: How high is your temperature?
How long have you had the fever?
Do you have any other symptoms like cough, headache, or body aches?

urgency_rules.self_care: Temperature under 100.4°F (38°C) in adults, no severe symptoms
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Fever lasting more than 3 days, or temperature 100.4-103°F with concerning symptoms
urgency_rules.emergency: Temperature above 103°F (39.4°C), fever with confusion, severe headache, stiff neck, difficulty breathing, or ANY fever in infant under 3 months

fever.analysis_hints: Fever is a symptom, not a disease - identify underlying cause. In children, behavior matters more than number.
fever.suggested_advice: Rest, stay hydrated, take acetaminophen or ibuprofen as directed. Monitor temperature every few hours.

follow_up_questions: Is your cough dry or productive (with mucus)?
How long have you had it?
Is it worse at night or during the day?
Are you coughing up blood or colored mucus?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild cough under 1 week with no breathing difficulty or fever
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Cough lasting more than 3 weeks, coughing up colored/thick mucus, persistent night cough, or cough with fever
urgency_rules.emergency: Coughing up blood, severe difficulty breathing, cough with chest pain, or cough in someone with heart/lung disease that suddenly worsens

cough.analysis_hints: Duration and character of cough help determine cause. Acute (<3 weeks) usually infection, chronic (>8 weeks) may be asthma, GERD, or other condition.
cough.suggested_advice: Stay hydrated, use humidifier, honey for cough relief (NOT for children under 1), elevate head when sleeping.

follow_up_questions: On a scale of 1-10, how severe is the pain?
Is it throbbing, dull, sharp, or pressure-like?
Where exactly does it hurt?
Is this a new type of headache for you?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild to moderate tension headache that responds to over-the-counter medication
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Frequent headaches (more than 2 per week), headaches that disrupt daily activities, or new pattern of headaches
urgency_rules.emergency: Sudden severe 'thunderclap' headache, headache with fever and stiff neck, headache after head injury, accompanied by vision changes/weakness/confusion, or 'worst headache of your life'

headache.analysis_hints: Sudden onset vs gradual, location (unilateral vs bilateral), and accompanying symptoms differentiate causes. Red flags: sudden onset, neurological symptoms, fever with neck stiffness.
headache.suggested_advice: Rest in quiet dark room, cold or warm compress (whichever feels better), acetaminophen or ibuprofen, stay hydrated.

follow_up_questions: Is the pain sharp, dull, or pressure-like?
Does it radiate to your arm, jaw, neck, or back?
Is it worse with breathing, movement, or exertion?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild chest muscle soreness after exercise or known strain, reproducible with movement
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Recurrent chest discomfort, chest pain that comes and goes, or chest pain with exertion that resolves with rest
urgency_rules.emergency: Crushing chest pressure, pain radiating to arm/jaw/back, shortness of breath, sweating, nausea with chest pain, or any chest pain lasting more than a few minutes - CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY

chest_pain.analysis_hints: ALWAYS take chest pain seriously - cardiac causes must be ruled out first. Heart attack signs: pressure/squeezing, radiation, associated symptoms. Musculoskeletal pain: sharp, reproducible with movement.
chest_pain.suggested_advice: EMERGENCY symptoms: Call 911, chew aspirin if no allergy. Non-emergency: See doctor same day, avoid exertion.

follow_up_questions: Is this sudden or gradual?
Do you have a history of asthma or lung problems?
Are your lips or fingernails blue?
Is it worse when lying down?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild breathlessness after exercise that resolves quickly with rest
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Shortness of breath with mild exertion, breathing difficulty when lying flat, or persistent wheezing
urgency_rules.emergency: Severe difficulty breathing, blue lips/fingernails, gasping for air, chest pain with breathing, or sudden onset severe breathlessness

breathing_difficulty.analysis_hints: Breathing difficulty is always concerning - assess severity, onset speed, and oxygen saturation. Asthma: wheezing. Heart failure: worse lying down. PE: sudden onset with chest pain.
breathing_difficulty.suggested_advice: Sit upright, loosen tight clothing, use prescribed inhaler if available. CALL 911 if severe or oxygen saturation below 90%.

follow_up_questions: Where exactly is the pain located?
Is the pain constant or cramping?
Do you have nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea?
Does movement make it worse?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild cramping or indigestion that improves with over-the-counter remedies, no fever
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Pain lasting more than 24 hours, pain that gradually worsens, or accompanied by persistent vomiting/diarrhea
urgency_rules.emergency: Severe pain in lower right abdomen (appendicitis), pain with fever and vomiting, sudden severe pain, rigid abdomen, blood in stool/vomit, or pain with pregnancy

stomach_pain.analysis_hints: Location is critical. Lower right: appendicitis. Upper right: gallbladder. Diffuse cramping: gastroenteritis. Rigid abdomen: peritonitis (emergency).
stomach_pain.suggested_advice: Rest, clear liquids, avoid solid foods until pain improves. Heating pad for cramps. Avoid NSAIDs if uncertain of cause.

follow_up_questions: How long have you been vomiting?
Can you keep any fluids down?
Do you have diarrhea too?
Any abdominal pain?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild nausea without vomiting, or 1-2 episodes of vomiting without dehydration signs
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Vomiting lasting more than 24 hours in adults (12 hours in children), signs of dehydration, or inability to keep fluids down
urgency_rules.emergency: Vomiting blood, severe abdominal pain with vomiting, signs of severe dehydration (no urination, extreme weakness, confusion), or head injury followed by vomiting

nausea_vomiting.analysis_hints: Most common: viral gastroenteritis. Watch for dehydration. Vomiting with severe pain suggests serious cause.
nausea_vomiting.suggested_advice: Sip clear fluids slowly, rest stomach 30-60 min after vomiting, gradual return to bland foods (BRAT diet), ginger tea may help.

follow_up_questions: How many episodes today?
Is there blood or mucus in the stool?
Do you have fever or abdominal pain?
Recent travel or new foods?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild diarrhea without blood, fever, or severe pain; able to stay hydrated
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Diarrhea lasting more than 2 days, moderate dehydration, fever with diarrhea, or recent antibiotic use
urgency_rules.emergency: Blood in stool with fever, signs of severe dehydration, severe abdominal pain, or diarrhea in elderly/immune-compromised with concerning symptoms

diarrhea.analysis_hints: Most cases viral and self-limiting. Blood + fever = bacterial. Recent antibiotics suggests C. difficile. Chronic (weeks) needs evaluation.
diarrhea.suggested_advice: Stay hydrated with water and electrolyte solutions, avoid dairy and fatty foods, eat bland foods when able, wash hands frequently.

follow_up_questions: Do you have fever?
Is it difficult to swallow?
Do you see white patches in your throat?
Is your voice hoarse?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild sore throat without fever, improves with home remedies
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Sore throat lasting more than a week, fever with sore throat, white patches (possible strep), or difficulty swallowing
urgency_rules.emergency: Severe difficulty swallowing or breathing, drooling, muffled voice, or rapid swelling of throat

sore_throat.analysis_hints: Viral pharyngitis most common. Strep throat: sudden onset, fever, no cough. Mononucleosis: severe fatigue, swollen lymph nodes.
sore_throat.suggested_advice: Gargle with warm salt water, throat lozenges, stay hydrated, acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain, rest voice.

follow_up_questions: Where exactly is the pain?
Did it start after lifting or injury?
Is there numbness or weakness in legs?
Does pain radiate down leg?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild to moderate back pain without neurological symptoms, able to move
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Back pain lasting more than 6 weeks, pain with numbness/tingling in legs, or pain that worsens despite rest
urgency_rules.emergency: Back pain with loss of bowel/bladder control, severe weakness in legs, numbness in groin area, or back pain after significant trauma

back_pain.analysis_hints: Most back pain is mechanical. Red flags: trauma, cancer history, fever, neurological deficits, bowel/bladder dysfunction.
back_pain.suggested_advice: Apply ice first 48 hours then heat, gentle movement (bed rest not recommended), NSAIDs, proper posture, gradual return to activity.

follow_up_questions: Is it a spinning sensation or lightheadedness?
Does it happen with position changes?
Do you have hearing changes or ringing in ears?
Any headache or vision changes?

urgency_rules.self_care: Brief lightheadedness with standing (postural), no other symptoms
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Recurrent dizziness episodes, dizziness with hearing changes, or persistent dizziness affecting daily activities
urgency_rules.emergency: Dizziness with chest pain, severe headache, vision changes, weakness, difficulty speaking, or loss of consciousness

dizziness.analysis_hints: Vertigo (spinning) usually inner ear. Lightheadedness: dehydration, low BP, anxiety. Neurological causes have other symptoms.
dizziness.suggested_advice: Sit or lie down immediately, stay hydrated, rise slowly from sitting/lying, avoid sudden head movements. Epley maneuver for BPPV.

follow_up_questions: How long have you been feeling this way?
Is your sleep quality good?
Have you lost or gained weight?
Any other symptoms?

urgency_rules.self_care: Fatigue after poor sleep, stress, or increased activity; improves with rest
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Persistent fatigue lasting more than 2 weeks despite adequate rest, fatigue with weight changes, or interfering with daily life
urgency_rules.emergency: Sudden severe weakness, fatigue with chest pain or breathing difficulty, or fatigue with confusion

fatigue.analysis_hints: Common causes: poor sleep, stress, depression, anemia, thyroid issues, infections. Chronic fatigue needs comprehensive evaluation.
fatigue.suggested_advice: Prioritize 7-9 hours sleep, regular exercise (counterintuitively helps), balanced diet, stress management, stay hydrated.

follow_up_questions: Where is the rash located?
Is it itchy, painful, or neither?
Have you started any new medications or products?
Does it blanch (turn white) when pressed?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild rash without fever or breathing issues, responds to antihistamines
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Rash that spreads rapidly, rash not improving after week, or rash with blistering
urgency_rules.emergency: Rash with fever and doesn't blanch when pressed (possible meningitis), rash with difficulty breathing or throat swelling (anaphylaxis), or rapidly spreading painful rash

rash.analysis_hints: Non-blanching rash with fever is emergency. Contact dermatitis: where product touched. Viral rash: often with fever, widespread.
rash.suggested_advice: Antihistamine for itching, cool compresses, avoid scratching, identify and remove trigger, moisturize skin.

follow_up_questions: Which joints are affected?
Is there swelling or redness?
Is it worse in morning or after activity?
Did you injure it?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild joint pain without swelling or fever, improves with rest and OTC medication
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Joint pain lasting more than 2 weeks, morning stiffness lasting over 30 minutes, or multiple joints affected
urgency_rules.emergency: Severe joint pain with fever, sudden severe swelling of joint, or joint that is hot and red with inability to move

joint_pain.analysis_hints: Osteoarthritis: worse with activity. Rheumatoid: morning stiffness, multiple joints. Septic joint: hot, red, fever (emergency).
joint_pain.suggested_advice: RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation), NSAIDs, gentle range of motion exercises, maintain healthy weight.

follow_up_questions: Is there drainage from the ear?
Do you have hearing changes?
Recent cold or allergies?
Is it worse when pulling on ear?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild ear discomfort without drainage or fever, possibly due to pressure changes
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Ear pain with drainage, lasting more than 2 days, or accompanied by hearing loss
urgency_rules.emergency: Severe ear pain with high fever, sudden hearing loss, dizziness with ear pain, or ear pain after head injury

ear_pain.analysis_hints: Children more prone to infections. Outer ear pain worse with touch. Middle ear: fever, fullness, hearing loss.
ear_pain.suggested_advice: Warm compress, OTC pain relievers, do NOT put anything in ear canal, see doctor if no improvement in 2-3 days.

follow_up_questions: Is vision affected?
Is there discharge or crusting?
Is there pain or just discomfort?
One eye or both?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild eye irritation or dryness without vision changes
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Persistent redness, discharge, or discomfort lasting more than 2 days
urgency_rules.emergency: Sudden vision loss, severe eye pain, eye injury, chemical exposure, seeing flashes/floaters suddenly, or vision changes with headache

eye_problems.analysis_hints: Conjunctivitis: red, discharge. Corneal injury: pain, tearing. Sudden vision changes or flashes: retinal emergency.
eye_problems.suggested_advice: Artificial tears for dryness, avoid rubbing eyes, proper contact lens hygiene. Chemical exposure: flush with water 15 minutes, then seek emergency care.

follow_up_questions: How long have you had symptoms?
Do you have fever?
Is your mucus clear or colored?
Are symptoms getting better or worse?

urgency_rules.self_care: Typical cold symptoms (runny nose, sneezing, mild cough) without high fever
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Symptoms lasting more than 10 days, symptoms worsening after initial improvement, or green/yellow mucus with facial pain
urgency_rules.emergency: Difficulty breathing, high fever unresponsive to medication, severe headache with vision changes

cold_symptoms.analysis_hints: Most colds viral, self-limiting 7-10 days. Worsening after day 5-7 suggests bacterial superinfection. Flu has more systemic symptoms.
cold_symptoms.suggested_advice: Rest, stay hydrated, saline nasal rinse, OTC decongestants and pain relievers, humidifier, throat lozenges.

follow_up_questions: Where do you feel it?
Is it constant or comes and goes?
Is it on one side or both?
Any weakness with it?

urgency_rules.self_care: Temporary numbness from position (sleeping on arm), resolves quickly
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Persistent or recurrent numbness, numbness in hands/feet bilateral, or numbness affecting function
urgency_rules.emergency: Sudden numbness on one side of body (stroke), numbness with weakness, facial drooping, or speech difficulty

numbness_tingling.analysis_hints: Sudden unilateral: stroke. Bilateral hands/feet: neuropathy (diabetes, B12). Carpal tunnel: hand numbness worse at night.
numbness_tingling.suggested_advice: Change position if positional, shake out limbs. Note pattern and report to doctor. EMERGENCY if sudden one-sided.

follow_up_questions: Where is the swelling?
Is it one side or both?
Does it pit when you press it?
Any pain or discoloration?

urgency_rules.self_care: Mild bilateral ankle swelling after prolonged sitting/standing
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Persistent swelling, swelling with shortness of breath, or new unexplained swelling
urgency_rules.emergency: Sudden swelling of one leg with pain (DVT), swelling with severe shortness of breath, or facial swelling with breathing difficulty

swelling.analysis_hints: Unilateral leg swelling with pain: DVT. Bilateral: CHF, venous insufficiency, medication. Facial: allergic reaction.
swelling.suggested_advice: Elevate legs, reduce salt intake, compression stockings, stay mobile. One leg swelling: seek immediate evaluation for DVT.

follow_up_questions: Do you soak through sheets?
Do you have fever or weight loss?
Any other symptoms?
Are you female and around menopause age?

urgency_rules.self_care: Occasional night sweats, room too warm, or perimenopausal with no other symptoms
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Persistent night sweats, night sweats with weight loss, fever, or fatigue
urgency_rules.emergency: Night sweats with severe symptoms, confusion, chest pain, or signs of serious infection

night_sweats.analysis_hints: Menopause common cause. With weight loss/fever: infections (TB), lymphoma. Medications can cause. Always evaluate if persistent.
night_sweats.suggested_advice: Keep room cool, moisture-wicking bedding, avoid alcohol/spicy food before bed. See doctor if persistent or with other symptoms.

follow_up_questions: How much hair are you losing?
Is it patchy or overall thinning?
Recent stress or life changes?
Other symptoms like fatigue or weight changes?

urgency_rules.self_care: Gradual thinning without other symptoms, 50-100 hairs daily normal
urgency_rules.doctor_visit: Sudden excessive hair loss, patchy bald spots, accompanied by other symptoms
urgency_rules.emergency: Rarely emergency unless part of systemic illness with severe symptoms

hair_loss.analysis_hints: Temporary: stress (3 months after event), pregnancy/postpartum. Medical: thyroid, iron deficiency, PCOS. Genetic: pattern baldness.
hair_loss.suggested_advice: Check thyroid and iron levels, reduce stress, gentle hair care, minoxidil for androgenetic alopecia, treat underlying cause.

cardiovascular_system.description: The heart and blood vessels pump blood throughout the body, delivering oxygen and nutrients while removing waste products.
key_facts: The heart beats about 100,000 times per day, pumping ~2,000 gallons of blood
Blood vessels if laid end-to-end would stretch about 60,000 miles
Coronary arteries supply blood to heart muscle itself
High blood pressure (hypertension) and high cholesterol are major risk factors for heart disease
Regular exercise strengthens the heart and improves circulation

respiratory_system.description: The lungs and airways enable breathing, exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide between air and blood.
key_facts: An average person breathes 20,000 times per day
The surface area of the lungs is roughly the size of a tennis court
Oxygen enters blood through tiny air sacs called alveoli
The diaphragm is the main breathing muscle
Smoking is the leading cause of preventable lung disease

digestive_system.description: The digestive tract breaks down food into nutrients for absorption, eliminating waste products.
key_facts: Digestion can take 24-72 hours from eating to elimination
The small intestine is about 20 feet long and does most nutrient absorption
The stomach produces hydrochloric acid to break down food and kill bacteria
Gut bacteria (microbiome) aid digestion and support immune function
Fiber promotes healthy digestion and prevents constipation

nervous_system.description: The brain, spinal cord, and nerves control voluntary and involuntary body functions, process sensory information, and enable thought and emotion.
key_facts: The brain contains ~86 billion neurons
Nerve signals can travel up to 268 mph
The brain uses ~20% of the body's energy despite being only 2% of body weight
Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers between nerve cells
The nervous system is divided into central (brain/spinal cord) and peripheral

immune_system.description: The immune system protects against infection and disease through innate and adaptive responses.
key_facts: White blood cells are the primary defense against pathogens
The immune system has memory - can recognize previously encountered threats
Vaccines train the immune system without causing illness
Autoimmune diseases occur when the immune system attacks the body's own tissues
Stress, poor sleep, and poor nutrition weaken immune function

endocrine_system.description: Glands produce hormones that regulate metabolism, growth, reproduction, mood, and many other functions.
key_facts: The pancreas produces insulin to regulate blood sugar
The thyroid controls metabolism through T3 and T4 hormones
Adrenal glands produce stress hormones (cortisol, adrenaline)
Sex hormones (estrogen, testosterone) regulate reproduction and secondary characteristics
Hormone imbalances can cause wide-ranging symptoms

skeletal_system.description: Bones provide structure, protect organs, enable movement with muscles, and produce blood cells.
key_facts: The adult human body has 206 bones
Bones constantly remodel - breaking down and rebuilding
Bone marrow produces red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets
Calcium and vitamin D are essential for bone health
Osteoporosis causes bones to become weak and brittle

healthy_diet_basics.description: A balanced diet provides essential nutrients for energy, growth, and disease prevention.
key_recommendations: Eat variety of fruits and vegetables (aim for 5+ servings daily, multiple colors)
Choose whole grains over refined grains
Include lean protein (poultry, fish, beans, nuts)
Limit processed foods, added sugars, and saturated/trans fats
Stay hydrated - drink water as primary beverage
Control portion sizes - use smaller plates
Limit sodium to reduce blood pressure risk

vitamins_minerals.description: Micronutrients essential for various body functions, needed in small amounts but critically important.
key_nutrients: Vitamin D: bone health, immune function (sunlight, fortified milk, supplements)
Vitamin B12: nerve function, red blood cells (animal products, supplements for vegans)
Iron: oxygen transport in blood (red meat, beans, fortified cereals)
Calcium: bones, teeth, muscle function (dairy, leafy greens, fortified foods)
Vitamin C: immune function, collagen production (citrus, peppers, berries)
Folate: cell division, prevents birth defects (leafy greens, fortified grains)

exercise_benefits.description: Regular physical activity is essential for physical and mental health.
key_benefits: Helps maintain healthy weight and body composition
Strengthens bones and muscles, prevents osteoporosis
Reduces risk of chronic diseases (diabetes, heart disease, some cancers)
Recommendation: 150 minutes moderate activity weekly, plus strength training

sleep_importance.description: Quality sleep is crucial for physical repair, mental consolidation, and overall health.
key_points: Adults need 7-9 hours per night; children and teens need more
Sleep allows body to repair tissues and consolidate memories
Consistent sleep schedule (same bedtime/wake time) improves quality
Poor sleep linked to obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and mental health issues
Sleep hygiene: dark quiet room, cool temperature, no screens before bed, avoid caffeine late

stress_management.description: Chronic stress affects physical and mental health; effective management is essential.
strategies: Mindfulness and meditation - reduces anxiety and improves focus
Deep breathing exercises - activates relaxation response
Time management - prioritize, delegate, say no

mental_health_basics.description: Mental health is as important as physical health; conditions are common and treatable.
key_points: 1 in 5 adults experiences mental illness yearly
Depression: persistent sadness, loss of interest, fatigue, hopelessness
Anxiety: excessive worry, panic attacks, physical symptoms
Treatment: therapy (CBT, etc.), medication, lifestyle changes, support groups
Seeking help is sign of strength, not weakness
Suicide prevention: call 988 (Suicide & Crisis Lifeline in US) if having thoughts of suicide

preventive_care.description: Regular screenings and healthy habits prevent disease or catch it early when most treatable.
recommendations: Annual physical exam with blood pressure, cholesterol, diabetes screening
Cancer screenings: mammogram (women 40-50+), colonoscopy (45+), cervical (21-65), prostate discussion (men 50+)
Stay current on vaccinations: flu annually, COVID boosters, Tdap every 10 years, shingles (50+), pneumonia (65+)

vaccination_importance.description: Vaccines train immune system to prevent serious diseases without causing illness.
key_facts: Vaccines contain weakened/inactive pathogens or instructions for immune response
Herd immunity protects those who cannot be vaccinated
Vaccines have prevented millions of deaths (smallpox eradicated, polio nearly gone)
Childhood vaccines: MMR, DTaP, polio, hepatitis B, varicella, HPV
Adult vaccines: flu, COVID, shingles, pneumonia, Tdap
Side effects usually mild (sore arm, low fever); serious reactions extremely rare
Benefits far outweigh risks

hygiene_infection_prevention.description: Good hygiene prevents spread of infections and protects personal and public health.
best_practices: Handwashing is #1 defense - wash with soap 20+ seconds, especially before eating and after bathroom/coughing
Cover coughs/sneezes with elbow, not hands
Stay home when sick with contagious illness
Don't share personal items (towels, razors, utensils)
Food safety: wash produce, cook meat thoroughly, refrigerate promptly
Hand sanitizer (60%+ alcohol) when soap unavailable

medication_safety.description: Safe medication use prevents adverse effects and interactions.
safety_rules: Tell every doctor ALL medications including supplements/herbs
Read labels carefully and follow dosing instructions
Don't mix medications without checking for interactions
Store properly (some need refrigeration), check expiration dates
Don't crush or split pills unless directed
Use one pharmacy for all prescriptions - they cross-check interactions
Generic medications are as effective as brand-name and much cheaper

first_aid_basics.description: Basic first aid knowledge can save lives in emergencies before professional help arrives.
essential_skills: CPR: Push hard and fast on chest center, 100-120 compressions/minute, 2 inches deep
Choking: Heimlich maneuver - abdominal thrusts until object dislodges
Bleeding: Apply direct pressure with clean cloth, elevate if possible
Burns: Cool water 10-20 minutes, cover with clean cloth, don't pop blisters
Fractures: Immobilize, ice (wrapped), elevate, don't move if spine injury suspected
Poisoning: Call Poison Control (1-800-222-1222 in US), don't induce vomiting unless directed
Recovery position: On side for unconscious breathing person
Everyone should take formal first aid/CPR class

when_to_seek_care.description: Knowing when to seek medical care and what level is appropriate.
guidelines: EMERGENCY (call 911): chest pain, difficulty breathing, severe bleeding, unconscious, stroke signs (FAST), severe allergic reaction, poisoning, severe trauma
ER visit: High fever (>103°F), severe pain, signs of meningitis, suspected fracture, deep cuts needing stitches
Urgent Care: Minor fractures, sprains, cuts, infections (ear, sinus, UTI), mild-moderate fever, rashes
Doctor's office: Ongoing concerns, checkups, chronic disease management, non-urgent symptoms
When in doubt: call your doctor's office or nurse hotline for guidance

cells_and_genetics.description: Fundamental biology of how the human body functions at microscopic level.
key_concepts: Body has ~37 trillion cells with ~200 different cell types
Cell parts: nucleus (DNA/control), mitochondria (energy), ribosomes (make proteins), membrane (controls entry/exit)
DNA contains genetic blueprint - ~3 billion base pairs in 23 chromosome pairs (46 total)
Genes can be dominant or recessive - inherit one set from each parent
Mutations can be beneficial, neutral, or harmful
Epigenetics: environment and lifestyle can affect gene expression

aging_process.description: Understanding normal aging helps distinguish it from disease.
normal_aging_changes: Gradual decline in vision and hearing
Skin becomes thinner and less elastic
Muscle mass decreases, bones become less dense
Memory and processing speed may slow slightly
Not normal aging: dementia, severe pain, depression, complete loss of function
Healthy aging: stay active, eat well, stay social, keep mind engaged, regular medical care

women_health.description: Health considerations specific to women across lifespan.
key_topics: Menstruation: 21-35 day cycle normal, periods 3-7 days, cramps manageable with heat/NSAIDs
Pregnancy: prenatal care essential, folic acid critical, avoid alcohol/smoking, regular checkups
Menopause: average age 51, symptoms (hot flashes, mood changes) manageable, HRT option to discuss with doctor
Breast health: monthly self-exam, mammograms 40-50+, most lumps not cancer but always get checked
Pelvic health: Pap smears 21-65 every 3 years, HPV vaccine prevents cervical cancer
Bone health: women higher osteoporosis risk, calcium/vitamin D important, weight-bearing exercise
Vaccines: follow CDC schedule, protect against serious diseases, safe and effective
Growth and development: regular checkups monitor milestones
Common illnesses: ear infections, croup, hand-foot-mouth, RSV, stomach bugs usually self-limiting
Fever in infants: any fever >100.4°F in baby under 3 months needs immediate medical attention
Warning signs: difficulty breathing, not drinking, inconsolable crying, lethargy, dehydration (no tears, dry mouth)
Nutrition: breast milk or formula first year, introduce variety of foods, limit sugar
Safety: car seats, helmets, supervision near water, poison-proof home

key_considerations: Fall prevention: remove tripping hazards, good lighting, non-slip mats, assistive devices, review medications (some cause dizziness)
Nutrition: adequate protein, calcium, vitamin D, B12 (often deficient), smaller frequent meals if appetite decreases
Stay active: walking, swimming, tai chi, balance exercises maintain independence and reduce falls
Mental health: social connections, hobbies, mental stimulation reduce depression and cognitive decline
Medication management: use pill organizers, pharmacy reviews, watch for interactions
Screenings: blood pressure, cholesterol, diabetes, cancer screenings, bone density, vision/hearing, cognitive assessments
Advance directives: document healthcare wishes, designate decision-maker

chronic_disease_management.description: Living successfully with long-term health conditions.
management_strategies: Learn about your condition thoroughly - knowledge is power
Monitor symptoms and vital signs (blood pressure, blood sugar, etc.)
Keep all doctor appointments and recommended screenings
Maintain healthy lifestyle: balanced diet, regular exercise, adequate sleep, stress management
Join support groups - connect with others facing similar challenges
Be your own advocate: ask questions, seek second opinions, keep organized health records
Address emotional wellbeing: chronic illness can cause frustration, anxiety, depression - counseling helps

diabetes_information.description: Diabetes is a condition where blood sugar is too high, either from insufficient insulin (Type 1) or insulin resistance (Type 2).
key_points: Type 1: autoimmune, body doesn't make insulin, requires insulin injections
Type 2: more common, body becomes resistant to insulin, often manageable with lifestyle and medications
Symptoms: increased thirst/urination, fatigue, blurred vision, slow healing wounds
Management: monitor blood sugar, HbA1c testing, healthy diet (control carbs), regular exercise, medications as needed
Complications if uncontrolled: nerve damage, kidney disease, vision loss, heart disease, foot problems
Regular checkups: eye exams, foot exams, kidney function tests

hypertension_information.description: High blood pressure (hypertension) strains the cardiovascular system and increases risk of heart attack, stroke, and kidney disease.
key_points: Normal: <120/80 mmHg, Elevated: 120-129/<80, High: ≥130/80
Often no symptoms - 'silent killer' - regular monitoring essential
Risk factors: age, family history, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, high sodium diet, stress, smoking
Lifestyle changes: lose weight, exercise regularly, reduce sodium, limit alcohol, quit smoking, manage stress
Medications if needed: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta blockers, diuretics, calcium channel blockers
Monitor at home: check regularly, keep log, bring to appointments

asthma_information.description: Asthma is a chronic condition where airways become inflamed and narrow, causing breathing difficulty.
key_points: Symptoms: wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, coughing (especially at night)
Triggers: allergens (pollen, dust, pet dander), exercise, cold air, smoke, respiratory infections
Management: avoid triggers, controller medications (inhaled corticosteroids), rescue inhaler for flare-ups
Action plan: know your triggers, recognize warning signs, know when to use rescue inhaler vs seek emergency care
Peak flow monitoring: measures how well air moves out of lungs
Well-controlled asthma allows normal activities

heart_disease_information.description: Heart disease includes conditions affecting the heart and blood vessels, the leading cause of death globally.
key_types: Coronary artery disease: plaque narrows arteries supplying heart
Heart failure: heart can't pump effectively
Valvular disease: heart valves don't function properly
Risk factors: high BP, high cholesterol, diabetes, smoking, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, family history
